image.altText: Two men wearing black, stand in front of a large freezer unit.

props.synopsis: A water cremation facility has just opened in Tasmania, with advocates touting it as a cheaper and greener alternative for those planning the end of their life.

title.children: Using water instead of fire to cremate loved ones could be the answer to 'funeral poverty'

image.altText: Ashton Jones looks at the camera and has a large yellow and blue parrot on his back

props.synopsis: Hobart man Caleb Adams will serve a prison sentence for manslaughter. The court has heard Adams was 'justifiably scared' when 34 year old Ashton Jones invaded his home, but that he had responded disproportionately to the event.

title.children: Ashton Jones died while attempting to break into his neighbour's home, his killer has been sentenced

image.altText: a woman is sitting at a table looking at a utility bill.

props.synopsis: Across Australia, a huge, forced migration is underway as consumers are shunted on to complex power prices. Just don't expect anyone to tell you about it.

title.children: A rude bill shock was the first most households heard about a monumental shift in Australia's energy system

image.altText: Former 2Day FM radio presenter, Mel Greig who was part of the duo who made the infamous royal prank call in 2012.

props.synopsis: In 2012, radio host Mel Greig made a royal prank call that shocked the world. One woman took her own life; another is haunted to this day. How did the joke go so wrong?

title.children: Mel made a prank call to a hospital where Kate Middleton was a patient. The nurse who answered ended up dead

image.altText: Man stands amid protestors wearing a sign: "UK rich state, mass, fuel, poverty, and Tory, austerity, end it now.

props.synopsis: When the Conservatives took power in Britain 14 years ago, they took a butcher's knife to budget spending. It was designed to save the country, but did it break it instead?

title.children: The UK is poorer, sicker and more unsafe. Did the Conservatives break Britain?

image.altText: A middle-aged white man with a beard holds his fingers to his thick-rimmed glasses.

props.synopsis: Some of the biggest names in publishing sat down with RN to talk all things literary for the Big Weekend of Books. Catch up on all the highlights from our jam-packed schedule in our blog.

title.children: Big Weekend of Books talks murder with Richard Osman and fantasy with Samantha Shannon

image.altText: Vladimir Putin sits before microphones with the words NICA on the background

props.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin says he will only end the war in Ukraine if Kyiv agrees to drop its NATO membership ambitions and hand over four provinces Moscow claims as its own — demands it has rejected.

title.children: Putin demands Ukraine drop NATO ambitions and hand over four provinces

image.altText: A composite image of an older man and an older woman smiling.

props.synopsis: It's murder or acquittal — after five weeks of evidence and arguments, the jury in Greg Lynn's murder trial over the deaths of two Victorian campers only have two options to choose from.

title.children: Insults fly in the courtroom as Greg Lynn's double-murder trial nears its final chapter

props.synopsis: Princess Catherine, who has been receiving preventative chemotherapy for cancer, says she will "join a few public engagements over summer", including Trooping the Colour in London on Saturday.

title.children: 'There are good days and bad days': Kate Middleton to make first public appearance as chemo continues

image.altText: Image of thylacine yawning with colours blue, green and sandy brown dirt added.

props.synopsis: Biotechnology company Colossal Biosciences says the Tasmanian tiger will return within the decade and it's laying the groundwork for the species' re-emergence.

title.children: Tassie wildlife sanctuary forms 'partnership of possibilities' with company aiming to bring thylacine back to life

image.altText: A head shot of John Bath

props.synopsis: Better Renting executive director Joel Dingham says sometimes even mentioning the prospect of going to tribunal can bring about a resolution.

title.children: John was told his rent was going up by $200. Then the eviction notice came

image.altText: Justin McInerney is tackled by an opponent while handballing

props.synopsis: A Dustin Martin milestone moment gave Richmond fans joy, but the Hawks had the final say at the MCG — now the Crows seek revenge on the high-flying Swans in Adelaide. Follow live.

title.children: Hawks spoil Dustin Martin's 300th game party before Crows, Swans wrap up the day in Adelaide

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: QT: Adelaide leads Sydney Swans by 11 points
We are under way at Adelaide Oval!
The crowd pays tribute to Dusty

image.altText: Man holds his forehead with his hand

props.synopsis: A US judge has ordered conspiracy theorist Alex Jones's personal assets be liquidated in order to pay $US1.5 billion to the families of victims from the Sandy Hook shooting, which he falsely claimed was a hoax.

title.children: Conspiracy theorist Alex Jones ordered to liquidate assets to pay families of Sandy Hook victims

image.altText: A large man wearing a grey suit speaks as he is surrounded by reporters holding microphones

props.synopsis: With Jarryd Hayne now out of jail following his sexual assault conviction being overturned, experts and advocates question whether the state's justice system is fit for purpose when it comes to sexual assault cases.

title.children: Why experts believe legal system is 'untenable' for sexual assault cases after Hayne verdict

image.altText: Image of a man kneeling on the ground with mounds of asbestos tailing waste around him. He is wearing a white singlet.

props.synopsis: In north-eastern New South Wales lies the small town of Baryulgil, where the remnants of an asbestos mine have drilled deep into the core of the community.

title.children: Years after Baryulgil's asbestos mine closed down, a deadly legacy remains with the people of this land

image.altText: A police car with its lights on.

props.synopsis: Victoria Police has cracked down on an alleged drug trafficking ring in Shepparton, arresting 11 people and seizing about $600,000 worth of drugs.

title.children: Cash, weapons and drugs seized as police uncover alleged trafficking ring in regional Victoria

image.altText: A crowd moves on and off a train at Perth Station from the Fremantle Line as transit guards stand by

props.synopsis: Transperth hands out hundreds of fines to school students for travelling without tickets, at the same time as offering them free public transport.

title.children: Transperth hands out more than 1,300 fines to school kids, despite saying they can travel for free

image.altText: A centre pivot irrigates hay

props.synopsis: With producers across the state looking far and wide for hay at a time of below-average rainfall, the mining giant's sudden drop in production comes as a blow to the livestock industry.

title.children: WA farmers rely on Rio Tinto for one crucial resource that's suddenly been cut by half

image.altText: Ed Le Brocq, smiling with arms crossed across chest, with black rimmed glasses, stands before large portrait of him as centaur.

props.synopsis: Centaurs can represent wisdom and knowledge. Jaq Grantford's portrait of Ed Le Brocq as a centaur tells the story of personal transformation.

title.children: Centaurs are transitional beings. One in particular captures ABC Classic's Ed Le Brocq's journey

image.altText: A red sign which reads: "Emergency Dept"

props.synopsis: A health department decision to install a "vacancy control committee" in order to make budget savings will put Tasmanians at risk and lead to "preventable deaths", the union representing allied health staff says.

title.children: Tasmanian health department to screen job vacancies in order to 'assist with budget repair'

image.altText: Cate Campbell looks down the pool

props.synopsis: Cate Campbell has reached the final of the 50 metres freestyle, giving her one last shot at making the Olympic swimming team for the Paris Games, as has pop-star turned swimmer Cody Simpson.

title.children: Cate Campbell, Cody Simpson claim final chance of Olympic selection

image.altText: A close up of Cortnee looking serious on the pitch.

props.synopsis: Matildas winger Cortnee Vine joins North Carolina Courage in the United States' National Women's Soccer League, sealing her club future until the 2027 Women's World Cup.

title.children: Matildas World Cup hero signs three-year deal with US NWSL club

image.altText: Graphic of Australian bank logos balancing on top of each other.

props.synopsis: Banks will need to tell customers when their savings interest rate changes, and the process for switching home loans will be simplified under a new federal government push to help consumers get better deals.

title.children: Government to 'nudge' banks to level with their customers on how to get a better deal

image.altText: Ladies in Black hero

props.synopsis: The book and then the film of Ladies in Black have been roaring successes. Now the women of the Goodes department store are back, taking on the challenges of 1960s Sydney.

title.children: Ladies in Black is back, this time in Sydney in 1961, with stars Miranda Otto and Debi Mazar at the helm

image.altText: A composite image of close up shots of Anthony Albanese and Peter Dutton.

props.synopsis: The recent political debates have seen Peter Dutton set the rules of play — it's a strategy that Anthony Albanese will need to counteract quickly to avoid trouble.

title.children: If Albanese doesn't move quickly, Dutton will continue to set the rules of play in political debate

image.altText: A teenage girl with blonde hair holds a mobile phone with both hands, with the phone in focus and her face obscured.

props.synopsis: Experts say sexual abuse using deepfake porn is likely to get worse, and it's not just AI sophistication that's enabling the behaviour. Exposure to misogynistic messages and degrading content online is "crushing" the empathy of young people.

title.children: How we've gone from a revival of 'make me a sandwich' jokes to a new era of AI 'revenge porn'

image.altText: A black bear sits in a cage rattling the fence.

props.synopsis: Japan recorded 219 bear attacks on people in the 12-months leading up to March this year, including six fatalities. The situation is becoming so severe that government officials have warned some bears are viewing humans as prey.

title.children: 'The bears know humans are present': How Japan's black bears became a deadly problem

image.altText: An aerial shot of a tropical blue lagoon, with beachfront bungalows, resorts and yachts.

props.synopsis: The Maldivian government says controversial land reclamation projects are necessary to fight rising sea levels and land scarcity. Experts say tourism is trumping the environment.

title.children: The Maldives is building new islands to fend off rising seas — and environmentalists are outraged

image.altText: A man in a suit and tie stands behind a bank of microphones speaking at a press conference

props.synopsis: Officials, diplomats and police in Canberra are furiously preparing for Chinese Premier Li Qiang, who will fly into Australia later today at a crucial time for Beijing and the Australian government.

title.children: China Premier to visit Australia today for the first time in seven years

image.altText: Gold bars piled on a wooden pallet.

props.synopsis: Mining is set to return to the Northern Territory's former centre of gold production, as prices for the precious metal hit record highs this year.

title.children: What was once considered Australia's richest gold mine is being brought back to life

image.altText: A wombat nuzzles up to a prisoners shoe.

props.synopsis: A regional Victorian prison program training inmates to rehabilitate injured native wildlife is giving more than just the animals a second chance.

title.children: Inmates nurse injured wildlife to health in prison program — but who is rehabilitating whom?

image.altText: A soccer goalkeeper reaching out to the ball.

props.synopsis: Chinese soccer fans are pouring their love — and money — into a Singaporean goalkeeper's food stall after his performance in a game this week indirectly helped China advance to the third qualifying round for the 2026 World Cup.

title.children: Why Chinese soccer fans are pouring money into a food stall run by Singapore's goalkeeper

image.altText: A line of crosses in red dirt

props.synopsis: The ban was imposed after a bump stock, which allows a gun to fire at a similar speed to an automatic weapon, was used in a deadly mass shooting in Las Vegas in 2017.

title.children: US Supreme Court overturns Trump-era ban on rapid-fire gun accessory

image.altText: A Thai monk touching a elephant newborn.

props.synopsis: Buddhist monks in Thailand bless twin baby elephants, one male and the other female, a week after their rare birth come close to being a tragedy.

title.children: Rare twin elephants in Thailand receive monks' blessings a week after their tumultuous birth
